Quantum theory is often described as a theory of states and operations. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the operations that can be performed on states of a quantum system. The characterization is in terms of a category of Hilbert spaces and continuous linear operators, and it is independent of any analytical structure. The characterization is a step toward a mathematical foundation for quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest to the biomedical sciences because of their potential as vaccine candidates and as models for studying the evolution of parasitism. However, the evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we report the genomes of two myxozoans, which are related to each other but distantly related to the model parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported animal genomes and that the myxozoan body plan is reduced in gene content. These findings provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. (Contains figures and tables.)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of zinc inhibition of the proton channel Hv1. We find that zinc binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the zinc-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how zinc inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, and the magnitude of the impact depends on the crop’s optimum temperature. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level differences in diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being matched in size and digestive physiology, some species were almost exclusively grass- and some were almost exclusively nongrass-eating, and that some species were highly similar in diet but were different trophic guilds. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity of large mammals may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the importance of plant diversity in structuring large mammal assemblages. This is a major advance in our understanding of the ecology of large mammals, and may have implications for their conservation and management. This article is protected by copyright. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. We also assess the impact of the CARES Act loans relative to grants. Our results suggest that grants may be more effective at increasing business resilience than loans.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. Our observations of the size distribution of floating plastic debris point at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Interstellar grains are the only direct witnesses of the early history of our solar system. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also found that a minority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. Our results provide constraints for the formation of the early solar system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects in the substantia nigra of the mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept of the potential of VX-765 to limit α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. This study also provides a rationale for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in the treatment of synucleinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the human body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controls blood pressure, and controls inflammation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control these functions by processing information from multiple sources. This paper describes the nature of the communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate its responses. The communication system is found to be highly effective in controlling the functions of the endothelium. The findings are important for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing new therapies for cardiovascular disease.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to monitor the pandemic and inform public health policy. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the data that are available are often not in a common format. We present the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available in a common format, and are updated daily. The data are available for researchers and policy makers to use in their own analyses. The data are also available for use in epidemiological model fitting. The data and software are available at https://github.com/COVIDcast/covidcast-api.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can change in response to the host’s diet. The gut microbiome is also a source of antimicrobial peptides that can be used to treat infections. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products that could be used to treat infections. This study also shows that anaerobic fungi are a source of antimicrobial peptides that could be used to treat infections.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups, but the influence of personality traits on social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as increased oxidative stress in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we develop a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple materials into composite structures that can precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized with irregular material distributions and exhibit organic shapes and motions. The responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed approach can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen carrier in the blood. The hemoglobin content of the blood is regulated by the expression of the globin genes. The globin genes are expressed in a developmental pattern that is controlled by the transcription factor BCL11A. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the erythroid lineage and that it mediates the developmental silencing of the globin genes. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells. This resistance requires sustained activation of mTORC1 and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR)C1-dependent induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or SCD1 sensitized ferroptosis in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are used in millions of patients worldwide. However, the mechanisms of action of these drugs are not fully understood. Here, we show that the three major classes of calcium channel blockers activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells. Our data indicate caution against the use of these drugs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of action of these drugs and may lead to the development of new drugs with a different mechanism of action. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated adaptive management, and was the first plan of its kind in the world. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test the influence of the NWFP on biodiversity. Our results show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations, but that the policy failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the importance of monitoring and adaptive management in the face of ongoing threats to biodiversity. This study provides a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of a policy on biodiversity. We hope that our findings will inform the development of similar policies in other regions. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study provides a proof of concept for the rational design of antibiotics. The approach presented here can be applied to other antibiotic classes and to other targets. We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of trainable parameters. The architecture is based on a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare the performance of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement and train, and can be applied to a wider range of problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that the use of an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the Younger Dryas cooling at ∼12.9 ka. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust (= 1.3), indicating a terrestrial origin of osmium (Os) in these samples. The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice results in the development of a variety of autoinflammatory diseases, including lymphoproliferation, autoimmunity, and inflammation of the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and salivary glands. These diseases are not fatal, but are accompanied by the development of Treg cells, which are important for the maintenance of self-tolerance.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, and to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles. We found that the origin of beetles and angiosperms coincided with the evolution of an arsenal of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls, and that these genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cell-wall degrading enzymes. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant cell walls. (Less)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning algorithm to improve the neutralizing activity of human antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We applied this algorithm to a human antibody, P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We demonstrated that our algorithm can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta, by ∼10- to 600-fold. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to mitigate the impact of SARS-CoV-2 variants on the global pandemic. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition, highlighting the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with a ∼12-fold decreased risk. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is a unique part of the Earth that is not affected by plate tectonics. The inner core is a key part of the Earth that is important for understanding the evolution of the Earth and the solar system. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still unclear. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core by proposing a two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is the only known site of evolution of the language faculty. Despite its importance, the brain’s language system is one of the most difficult cognitive abilities to study. Here, we show that a large body of neuroscience data can be explained by a computational model of language processing. This provides a new avenue for understanding the human language comprehension system in the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still in its infancy. It is now entering scientific computing, but it is not clear how to make it work. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a paradox, because the existence of stable NNs is not a sufficient condition for the success of DL. We introduce a classification theory describing conditions under which stable NNs can be computed by an algorithm. We prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a renewed interest in the psychology of exponential growth. In the 1970s, a classic experiment was conducted to study the human ability to understand exponential growth. The experiment’s critical design flaws were only recently identified. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the cause of the disease has been debated for even longer. In this study, we sequenced the genome of a human pathogen that is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We found that the genome is highly similar to that of Mycobacterium leprae, the causative agent of Hansen's disease, suggesting that the two pathogens are still closely related. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and may lead to the identification of new targets for the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources for quantum information processing. They are also the two main ingredients of the second law of thermodynamics. However, the interplay between them is still poorly understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems is governed by a simple scaling law. This law is based on the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, which is a well-established result in the context of unitary time evolution. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, which is integrable, and we find perfect agreement with the exact results. This result is a milestone in the study of the entanglement dynamics, as it opens the way to the exact computation of the entanglement in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus, which is associated with severe adverse events. To overcome this limitation, we developed a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. We show that the vaccine is highly attenuated, safe, and protective in hamsters. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to control the pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague in Europe is poorly understood. Here, we present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector, which fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by human ectoparasites during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our model can be used to study the historical spread of plague in Europe and to understand the role of ectoparasites in the spread of other infectious diseases. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive abilities of animals. The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton, and they are dynamically remodeled by a variety of proteins. One of the most important proteins that regulate the dynamics of actin filaments is cofilin. Cofilin is a small protein that is able to sever actin filaments. However, how it does so is not understood. Here, we show that cofilin binds to actin filaments in a mechanical manner, and that the binding induces a mechanical torque that enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that this mechanism is a general principle of actin filament severing.

Fructose, a sweetener commonly used in soft drinks, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to sucrose (table sugar). However, the results of this study suggest that the health benefits of fructose may be limited. Ingestion of fructose relative to glucose resulted in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promoted greater hunger and desire for food and a willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also have implications for the interpretation of neuroimaging studies of food cues and food-approach behavior in a fasted state.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a faster settlement from Africa than from Asia. Finally, we found that a few centuries are enough to produce genetic structure in the island. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the world. It also provides a tool to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on a social network. This is a form of emotional contagion, which is well established in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they do not see the other person. This work has implications for the design of social networks, and for the design of interventions to improve mental health.

The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a relatively new area of research. In this study, we investigate the impact of one of the most common modifications, pseudouridine (Ψ), on protein synthesis. We find that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the activation of the elongation factor EF-Tu. We also find that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid addition to the growing peptide chain. These findings have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better physical and mental health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, education, and health. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the underlying drivers remain unclear. We use a model of the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the unique requirements of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. It replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature of the host. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to a variety of environmental signals, and have evolved a wide range of sensing systems to appropriately respond to environmental signals. Here we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa detects contact with surfaces on short timescales using the mechanical activity of its type IV pili, a major surface adhesin. This signal transduction mechanism requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pilus retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Like other chemotaxis pathways, pili-mediated surface sensing results in a transient response amplified by a positive feedback that increases type IV pili activity, thereby promoting long-term surface attachment that can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. The methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like chemosensor PilJ directly interacts with the major pilin subunit PilA. Our results thus support a mechanochemical model where a chemosensory system measures the mechanically induced conformational changes in stretched type IV pili. These findings demonstrate that P. aeruginosa not only uses type IV pili for surface-specific twitching motility, but also as a sensor regulating

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the number of pesticides is constantly increasing. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which is of great importance for the future of our planet. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is not only a problem for the environment but also for the biodiversity of aquatic ecosystems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also infected a wide variety of animals, including deer, and can be transmitted between animals and humans. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer in Iowa, USA. This study highlights the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the problem, the consequences of the dams, and the solutions. We find that the problems are caused by the industry’s focus on maximizing profits, the lack of transparency in the decision-making process, and the lack of consideration of climate change. We propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein in the brain, which is believed to be the result of sustained inflammation. However, the earliest stages of the disease, when the pathology is still limited to the brain, are characterized by a plaque-independent inflammatory response. We show that neurons, which are the primary cell type in the brain, are also the source of this response. Our findings provide a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a detailed faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread there. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the earliest evidence from the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the folding pathway is not known for many proteins. The folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, was studied in great structural detail by a new method that measures the extent of protein hydration. The results show that the folding of the protein proceeds in distinct steps, and the steps are not adjacent in the sequence. The steps are not adjacent in the sequence.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and are known to function as precursors to RNA caps. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the caps of Np4-capped RNAs, also removes the caps of other RNAs, including those capped with di- and triphosphorylated dinucleoside tetraphosphates. We also show that RppH prefers to remove capped RNAs over their uncapped counterparts, and that the unique manner in which capped substrates bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for the differential impact of RppH on capped and uncapped RNAs, and could have major implications for the reprogramming of gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Despite the advances in the treatment of sepsis, the mortality rate remains high. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression induced by sepsis are not fully understood. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study could also be extended to other diseases where arginine is involved in the pathogenesis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, without the need for doping or heat treatment. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for applications.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the pharmaceutical industry and the scientific community. The study of the antifungal activity of peptides is of particular interest because of the lack of effective alternatives to fungicides. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, the first of its kind, and its antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate the potential of this peptide as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This study provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a new class of fungicides. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. We used proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determined the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We found that female-derived proteins associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work also provides a resource for future studies of the molecular basis of sex differences. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain in VWF binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and that force application switches the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The results are important for understanding the role of conformational changes in protein function. They also provide a tool for studying the role of force in protein function. The results are also important for understanding the role of force in the function of other proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of the virome on human health. We find that the human virome is highly associated with disease, and that the human microbiome is more complex than previously thought.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the process and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties. The instrument is able to measure aerosol and cloud properties with high spatial and temporal resolution. This instrument is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean, the period of time when life first emerged, is of particular interest because it is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life on Earth. We present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the Archean based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient DNA. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the Earth decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that BK channels can exhibit C-type inactivation with a mutation that causes a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in BK channels is closed state-dependent and can occur during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or with decreased intracellular calcium ([Ca2+]i). We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help to understand the mechanism of K+ channel regulation. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 207 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017. The Plasmodium parasite infects the red blood cell (RBC) and invades the host circulatory system, where it replicates and causes disease. The invasion process is poorly understood, and the parasite’s interaction with the RBC is thought to be mediated by a number of adhesins. Here, we show that the interaction between the parasite’s erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) and the RBC’s glycophorin A receptor alters the physical properties of the RBC, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This is the first time that we have been able to show that the parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell to facilitate invasion. This finding could lead to the development of new strategies to combat the disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. It is a semiconductor with a wide bandgap, but its electronic properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that strain can be used to tune the electronic properties of diamond. We demonstrate that strain can be used to tune the electronic properties of diamond. We demonstrate that strain can be used to tune the electronic properties of diamond.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza severity. Our study may also have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapies. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a bottom-up, word-by-word fashion. However, the neurophysiological basis of this process is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s response to the words in a sentence varies with each successive word but suddenly increases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with the predictions of a model of phrase construction and provides initial evidence for a neural implementation of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be a key component of the brain’s efficient representation of the world.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer therapy. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level but differ in their regulation. We show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated in different tissues, which may be important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. It is also a region that is involved in the development of obesity. Here we describe a circuit that is activated by electrical stimulation of LH and that promotes overeating. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is a major factor determining crop productivity. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, which fix nitrogen only in contact with the host plant, could be a major breakthrough in the field of sustainable agriculture. We have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, which could be used to develop a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis.

Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation in the Amazon. However, the effectiveness of these systems in deterring deforestation is unclear. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured hearing organ that is not constrained by the body. The web is a hyperacute acoustic antenna that is more sensitive to sound than the spider’s body. The spider can adjust and regenerate the web to detect different sounds. The spider can also hear without a body, which is a unique feature for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The health and climate impacts of air pollution are well known, but the benefits of reducing them are not. We estimate the number of lives saved by a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We show that it can save 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide, and up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. The benefits are large, especially in India and China, and can be extended to other regions by reducing the emissions of other pollutants. The results show the importance of a global effort to reduce air pollution.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on global health and the global economy. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. We report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 that is amenable to large-scale production. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle to reduce weight loss in hamsters. These results provide a potential platform for the development of a subunit vaccine against SARS-CoV-2.

The development of neural crest-derived tissues is a complex process involving multiple signaling pathways. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK-like receptors (alkals) are involved in the regulation of neural crest development. We provide evidence that the three zebrafish ALK-like receptors are activated by secreted ALKAL proteins, which are likely to be encoded by the same gene family. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of zebrafish ALK-like receptors in neural crest development. This study also provides a model for studying the role of ALK-like receptors in human diseases.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for some of the deadliest outbreaks in human history. The emergence of Y. pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-established story, but the details of its evolution and ecology during the formative years of its emergence are still poorly understood. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Y. pestis genomes from across Eurasia, which allowed us to explore the diversity of the pathogen during this period. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, which will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of HM. The findings also have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of HM.

The conversion of native grasslands to intensive crop production has led to massive losses of soil organic carbon (SOC) to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of different soil health management practices in increasing SOC storage on these soils remains highly uncertain. We show that soil management strategies that maintain or restore perennial vegetation, such as rotational grazing of pastures, can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC in the more stable mineral-associated fraction. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification of zoonotic potential of emerging viruses and the prioritization of research and public health interventions.

Nectar is a reward that many animals seek out in plants. The color of nectar is often an important cue for animals in deciding whether to visit a plant. Here, we show that the color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus, a plant visited by gecko pollinators, is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also show that the same alkaloid is produced in two other plants visited by gecko pollinators, suggesting that this trait is convergent. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color in plants and the role of alkaloids in this process. It also provides a new tool for the study of vertebrate pollination. The genetic landscape of Europe is a complex mosaic of genetic contributions from different parts of the continent and from outside. However, the genetic history of the period between the migrations of the 5th century and the Viking Age is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived in the late 5th/early 6th century. Our results indicate that they had a genetic ancestry that was not present in modern Europeans. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during this period and may have implications for the understanding of the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the cross-species transmission of MERS-CoV and may facilitate the development of more effective countermeasures against future bat-

The emergence of new pathogens and the spread of existing ones are a global concern. In resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, the capacity to detect and respond to emerging pathogens is limited. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our results highlight the potential of mNGS to detect a broad range of pathogens in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied in other resource-limited settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate the impact of emerging pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in eukaryotes. It is a large enzyme that is anchored to the PCNA sliding clamp to form a holoenzyme. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study provides a unique perspective on the stability of a large enzyme holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for the development of new inhibitors of lagging strand synthesis. This is an important area of research as the development of new therapeutics for cancer and other diseases requires a better understanding of the mechanisms of replication. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, the replication of genetic information was accomplished by RNA molecules. In the laboratory, the evolution of RNA molecules that can replicate themselves has been achieved by in vitro evolution. Here, we report the evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules. This is the first step toward the reconstruction of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of these patients are summarized. The results show that the immune system of these patients is in a state of imbalance, and the inflammatory storm is the main cause of death. Tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can effectively reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also highly toxic at high concentrations. The existence of a fungal natural product that binds copper and impacts cellular copper content is a significant discovery. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, on Mars is a significant discovery. The presence of tridymite in a laminated mudstone at the base of a central peak in Gale crater, Mars, is consistent with the hypothesis that the peak was formed by a volcanic eruption. The tridymite is cogenetic with other crystalline phases, such as feldspar and cristobalite, and is possibly derived from a silicic volcanic source in the crater wall/rim/central peak region. The amorphous silica is precipitated from variable aqueous solutions, and the crystalline magnetite is detrital. The presence of the mixed-cation salts and oxides and possibly the crystalline magnetite (otherwise detrital) are primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products derived from multiple aqueous solutions with variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is consistent with the hypothesis that the sedimentary rocks in the region were deposited in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment.

Frost is a major environmental factor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not adapted to the new frost regimes. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of these cells in the pathogenesis of the disease is unclear. We found that the development of colitis required the development of a subset of Th17 cells to Th1-like cells, which were dependent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (truncated)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. Importantly, we find that motor neurons are not the only target of astrocytes from ALS patients. This opens up the possibility of studying and treating astrocyte-derived toxicity in ALS.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. We now show that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to enhance the colonization of the tick. We also show that the ability of Anaplasma to modify the tick microbiota is mediated by the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which encodes a protein with several properties, including the ability to alter bacterial biofilm formation. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to influence the gut microbiota and enhance transmission. This work also provides a framework for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds, as it is the key to understanding the origin of flight. However, the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group is poorly understood, and the diversity of early members is limited. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group, and it is the second earliest member of the Pygostylia.

We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system. This is not a new idea, but it is one that has been overlooked in climate models. We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to the climate system, and that it is important to include the stratosphere in climate models.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. In this study, we describe a new mechanism of color change, which is based on the binding of biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood, to a specific protein. This mechanism is present in many vertebrates, and it is the basis for the color of many animals.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. It is characterized by the ability of some cells to initiate tumors and to give rise to other cells that have the capacity to initiate tumors. These cells are called cancer stem cells (CSCs). We report that hypoxia induces expression of a m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn induces expression of pluripotency factor NANOG, which is a marker of CSCs. This study provides a mechanism for how hypoxia induces CSCs. It also provides a target for cancer therapy.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we present a simple and objective method to determine the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that the production of parchment was a complex process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This process may have been possible because of the use of parchment in a wide range of sizes and thicknesses. The results also suggest that the use of abortive or newborn animals was not a necessary part of the process. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future.

The age of the extinction is a key control on the timing of ecosystem reorganization and the timing of the recovery of the biota. The age model presented here is based on a precise age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary. The age model is based on a new set of U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age model provides a precise age for the onset of the extinction and the timing of ecosystem reorganization. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the regulation of various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression.
