The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the human ACE2 receptor. We find that the D614G mutation has led to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor. This study provides a structural basis for understanding the impact of the D614G mutation on the infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) to the case of Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our projections imply that the Black−White life expectancy gap will increase from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections underscore the importance of addressing structural inequalities in health outcomes and mortality.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in the study of the properties of matter under extreme conditions, such as high pressure. Here, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales are explicative and predictive. This work is a step forward in the understanding of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, including wildfires. However, the impact of climate change on fire activity is highly uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, such as population growth, urbanization, and economic development, can have a large influence on fire activity, and that these changes can reduce warming. Our results highlight the importance of human demography in shaping the future of fire and the carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic relationships. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and delivery of these nutrients are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We also show that the timing of chitin provision is critical for the persistence of the symbiont, and that the provision of chitin is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which increases the oxygen available to the symbionts. These results provide a mechanistic explanation for the timing of nutrient provision in animal-microbe mutualisms. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope it will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results have implications for the understanding of the spread of the plague in Europe and the development of the Black Death pandemic. (Less)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases of marine invertebrates. The disease has been observed in at least 20 species of asteroids, which are important ecosystem engineers and prey for a variety of species. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is transmitted vertically from parent to offspring. The virus is also present in the environment, which may facilitate the spread of the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a disease with a poor prognosis, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP as a treatment for AML. This approach could be extended to other targets that are expressed on leukemic stem cells. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a faster settlement from Africa than from Asia. Finally, we found that a few centuries are enough to produce genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean. It is also a unique case to study the impact of geography on the genomic diversity of human populations. This study will help to understand the history of the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings provide insight into the evolution of dual

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs), which have the potential to evade the immune protection provided by vaccines and prior infection. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning approach to enhance the neutralizing activity of human antibodies against VOCs. We applied this approach to a human antibody, P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our approach enabled the optimization of the CDR sequences of P36-5D2 to improve its binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our results suggest that our approach can be used to engineer other protein molecules, such as monoclonal antibodies, to improve their neutralizing activity against emerging VOCs. This approach may be useful in the development of antibody drug candidates for the current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, providing information on crop status that is used to estimate crop production and monitor crop conditions. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily used in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting crop condition index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of leveraging the network of “people as sensors” to provide a more complete picture of agricultural production and conditions. This can be used to improve the accuracy of agricultural forecasts and provide early warnings of crop anomalies.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is characterized by the ability to store and integrate information over time. The mechanisms that support this ability are not well understood. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the human brain. Our model is based on the idea that memory is supported by the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to scientists and policy makers. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it is marked by a gradual change in the environment and the lifestyle of the organism. We present a model of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the loss of photosynthesis is linked to the loss of function in all plastid genes, which is in turn linked to the loss of the host. Our findings suggest that the loss of function in plastid genes is a gradual process, with bursts of gene losses occurring in parallel with periods of relaxed selection. The evolutionary rates and selection pressure coevolve with the macrostructural and microstructural changes in the plastid genome. The evolutionary rates reach several new rate equilibria during the process of functional reduction. These equilibria are linked to the modified turnover rates of the proteins in the heterotrophic plastids. Our findings provide a framework for understanding the molecular evolution of plastid genomes during the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. They also provide a model for the molecular evolution of the genomes of other organelles.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of such a drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the drought risk in SSA is not limited to the 2015–2017 event, but is likely to increase in the future. This study provides a better understanding of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the recent drought and will help to mitigate its future impacts. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, is significant because it represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy to chemical energy. The conversion of light energy to chemical energy is achieved by chlorophyll, a molecule that captures the light energy and transfers it to the reaction center. The biosynthesis of chlorophyll is a highly productive biological pathway, and the biosynthesis of chlorophyll is the focus of this article.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological hallmark of neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Neuroinflammation is regulated by a variety of signaling pathways, including mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) and phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/AKT. However, the roles of these pathways in neuroinflammation are not fully understood. In this study, we found that apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a key regulator of neuroinflammation in EAE. ASK1 is highly expressed in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages or astrocytes reduced neuroinflammation in the later stage of EAE. These results suggest ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the roles of glial cells in neuroinflammation. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to anthropogenic warming. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a molecular mechanism for autism and a target for drug development. It also provides a model system for studying the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This study is expected to contribute to the understanding of the etiology of autism and to the development of treatments.

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the prevalence of negativity biases in news content across a large number of countries and continents. It finds that, on average, news content is more negative than entertainment content, and that this negativity bias is present in both developed and developing countries. It also finds that, on average, individuals are more negative in their reactions to news content than to entertainment content. The implications of these findings for the news media and for the study of human cognition and behavior are discussed.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, which result in hematological abnormalities and a Stormorken-like syndrome. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous and that the spreading of aggregates is dependent on the fusion of vesicles. We also show that the release of aggregates requires the activity of the endocytic machinery. These findings provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. This work also provides a platform for studying the spread of other protein aggregates in the brain. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses that cause severe outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) H1N1 infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus one-carbon metabolism is a critical metabolic pathway. In this study, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, namely, the deficiency of one-carbon metabolism. We identify a small molecule that targets both serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2, and we show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells. We also show that cancer cells have unique metabolic vulnerabilities, and that one of these vulnerabilities is the deficiency of glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, and we have identified a small molecule that targets this vulnerability. This study has implications for cancer treatment, and for the development of new drugs. It also has implications for understanding the role of one-carbon metabolism in normal cell growth. This study is a step toward understanding the role of one-carbon metabolism in cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. We show that the proteins that form inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a unifying explanation for the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS and other neurodegenerative disorders. This approach can be applied to other neurodegenerative diseases to identify metastable proteins that are likely to be coaggregating in inclusions.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that the results presented here will be of interest to researchers in the fields of atom optics, photonic crystals, and quantum information science. The origin of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the early evolution of the aquatic angiosperms is even less understood. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from lithographic limestone deposits in the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. Montsechia is an aquatic angiosperm that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens of Montsechia reveals that it is sister to Ceratophyllum, a plant that lives and reproduces above the surface of the water. Montsechia is the earliest known aquatic angiosperm, and its age raises questions about the very early evolution of the aquatic angiosperms.

Parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous human pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (63.9–99.7% genome coverage) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily over the last century, but the rate of rise has accelerated in recent decades. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y, using a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data. We find that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This implies that global mean sea level could rise 65 ± 12 cm by 2100 compared with 2005.

Pain is a major public health problem, with the elderly reporting more pain than younger adults. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and may have important implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group in a reaction catalyzed by tryptophan synthase. This study demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe coronavirus infection with a high case fatality rate. There is a need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral replication that has been shown to be effective against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Here, we tested the efficacy of prophylactic and therapeutic remdesivir treatment in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Prophylactic treatment prevented the development of clinical disease, while therapeutic treatment reduced the severity of the disease. These data support the development of a clinical trial of remdesivir in MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit to the global community. (truncated)

Suspension rates in US schools are high, and the consequences of suspension are severe. We tested whether teachers could be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. We found that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions, and that these mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. Our findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the replication and transcription of DNA. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and is a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the majority of people in high-income countries have remained largely unchanged for decades, and are not likely to change significantly in the near future. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a significant impact on meal selection behavior. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased by the majority of people in a country, and could be easily implemented in a wide range of settings. This study provides a clear example of how nudging can be used to promote sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We applied a quantitative proteomics approach to study the surfaceome of a collection of six oncogenes, and found that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. We complement the surfaceome data with glycoproteomics, and found massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer. (Show more)

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that 1) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, 2) universal vote-by-mail does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and 3) universal vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings are likely to be of interest to scholars and policymakers alike.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. The SARS-CoV-2 virus has been shown to be able to evade the immune system, and the molecular basis for this is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. We show that the structure is similar to that of SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, but with the addition of two unique interfaces. These interfaces may be important for the immune evasion and virus spread activities of ORF8. This structure will be useful for understanding the function of ORF8 and for the development of antiviral therapeutics.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying hypoxia-induced edema are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this edema is associated with an up-regulation of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) system in the cortex. We also show that the up-regulation of CRF and CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in the cortex is necessary for hypoxia-induced edema. Finally, we show that the up-regulation of CRF and CRFR1 is associated with an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of hypoxia-induced edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (truncated)

The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being generated is growing exponentially. The sophistication of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is also growing exponentially. This paper describes a new challenge that is being created by this revolution. The challenge is to use the data to find the strongest associations, but to do so in a way that is fair and unbiased.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vitro. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells (ECs) from human adult skin fibroblasts using the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2). ETV2 is a transcription factor that is important for both endothelial and hematopoietic development. We demonstrate that ETV2 alone can induce the formation of functional ECs in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. It also provides a potential therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders. This study may also provide a new strategy for the generation of ECs for the regeneration of organs. (truncated)

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a large family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In the last decade, two new RTKs have been identified, ALKAL1 and ALKAL2, which are oncogenes in human cancer. Here, we show that zebrafish deficient in ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 display a severe defect in pigment patterning. We further show that these defects are mediated by a third ligand of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2, which is encoded by zebrafish. This study establishes a physiological link between ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 and their ligand and demonstrates that the ligand is essential for zebrafish pigment patterning. These findings are important for understanding the function of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 in vivo and for developing new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular basis of T2D is well known, the treatment of T2D is still a challenge. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Our study provides a potential target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the most important pathogens of humans and animals. They cause annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is composed of eight segments, which are packaged into virions. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the replication of the virus, but the molecular details of the packaging process are unknown. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of two viral RNA segments in the influenza A virus. This mechanism is sequence dependent and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the packaging process of the influenza A virus. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. Wildfire is a natural process that is essential to the health of many ecosystems. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly approach to pest control. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of the disease are not fully understood, but the recent availability of a nonhuman primate model has allowed for the development of a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV. We present a mathematical analysis of the model, which allows for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We also assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication. Our results can be used to guide the development of a treatment for ZIKV. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a major threat to the health of coral reefs worldwide. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a consequence of the inability of the coral host to maintain the health of its algal symbionts. We show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral host to heat stress are a consequence of altered nutrient cycling within the coral–algal symbiosis. This feedback loop is driven by the energy limitation of the coral host and the degradation of the algal symbiont, which in turn promotes the growth of the algal symbiont and retention of photosynthates. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that separates the host from the external environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium loses its barrier function, leading to systemic infections and death. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment is able to trigger a regenerative response in the host, which in turn triggers the tumor to grow. We also show that the microbiome is able to trigger a regenerative response in the host, which in turn triggers the microbiome to grow. Our work identifies a mechanism by which the tumor microenvironment is able to trigger a regenerative response in the host, and highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work also provides a model for the study of regenerative responses in other tissues. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is an important treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to it. We found that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. This enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. We also found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still a matter of debate. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a climate response. This response is consistent with the timing and magnitude of the climate changes observed in the Southern Hemisphere during the last deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the importance of inland fisheries in regions where alternative sources of nutrition and employment are scarce. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. Aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost after birth. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the sensory dendrite, and it is enhanced by disrupting L-type calcium channels or elevating cAMP. We also identify a form of regeneration that is dependent on the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. These findings provide a framework for understanding the molecular control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may be more regenerative than previously thought.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. It is also the target of many human diseases. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in regions of the genome called hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The distribution of hotspots is similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the ancient mechanisms of recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect conserved eukaryotic processes.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the generation of cognitive and behavioral functions. The present study provides a detailed description of the resting state organization of the human brain, based on the analysis of metabolic signals, which are not subject to the fluctuations of the BOLD signal. The results show that the dominant metabolic network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant metabolic network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. The results also show that the dominant metabolic network is reduced in the early stages of the disease, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study provides a detailed description of the resting state organization of the human brain, which can be used to study the functional organization of the brain in health and disease.

RNA is a ubiquitous molecule that is involved in many biological processes. It is often modified, and these modifications can have important effects on the function of the RNA. In this study, we describe a 5′ modification of RNA that is found in both the nucleus and the mitochondria of yeast cells. We show that this modification is not found on transfer RNAs or ribosomal RNAs, and that it is not found on messenger RNAs that are involved in translation. This modification may have important effects on the function of the RNA.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We found that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) in people with diabetes. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the metabolic memory phenomenon.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with the presence of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects, which may be involved in the development of the gut barrier alteration. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. These compounds are produced during ripening, and the biosynthesis of many of them is unknown. We have identified a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce these compounds. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and the identification of this gene will facilitate the development of improved cultivars with enhanced flavor. The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large number of neurons that are tuned to different aspects of the environment, such as the location of walls and the direction of the animal’s head. The precise organization of these neurons is not known. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the organization of the neurons is similar to that in the hippocampus, but the neurons are more strongly tuned to the location of the walls in the environment. This work provides a detailed view of the organization of the neurons in MEC and their relationship to the neurons in the hippocampus. It will help us to understand how the brain represents the location of the animal in space.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering of the host is required for flowering of the parasite. This is a unique means of flowering regulation, which is likely to be important for the synchronization of flowering in the host–parasite interaction.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is characterized by the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra and the loss of striatonigral fibers in the striatum. Here, we describe a previously unidentified subsystem of the nigrostriatal system, the striosome–dendron bouquet, which is formed by the striosomes, the dopamine-containing dendrites, and the nigral cell bodies. The striosome–dendron bouquets are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when two people are “clicking” or “not clicking.” But how do we know when two people are “clicking” with each other? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for the regulation of heart rate in response to changes in the environment. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and it is important to understand the mechanisms that govern its function. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the function of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant physiology has been debated for decades. Although Si has been shown to enhance plant resistance against abiotic stresses, the role of Si in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been well understood. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in plants with RNAi-mediated gene silencing of jasmonate biosynthesis and perception genes. These results suggest that Si and JA interact in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the function of Si in plant resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still unclear. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that is characterized by the ability to store and integrate information over time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by a mechanism that reduces the firing rate of neurons. We show that this mechanism can provide memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biotechnology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the internalization of DNA nanostructures into plant cells and the corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biotechnology community.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of the nutrients that enter lakes and rivers come from nonpoint sources, such as agricultural fields and urban areas. However, the role of small tributaries in delivering nutrients to coastal areas is largely unknown. We show that small tributaries deliver a disproportionately large amount of nutrients to the world’s fifth largest lake, Lake Michigan. These findings have implications for the management of coastal ecosystems, as well as for the design of future monitoring and regulatory efforts. Our results suggest that small tributaries may be a significant source of coastal eutrophication, and that efforts to reduce nutrient loading in these areas may be more effective than previously thought. We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is highly selective in the chemical states it can access. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. We show that this bias is a consequence of the interplay between the environment and the network, and that it is not present in simpler models of chemical networks. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of catalytic systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the effects of the antibodies on the brain circuit are at the level of the synapses. We validate a model of the cortical microcircuitry and show that the key synaptic parameters are the key determinants of the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We then show that the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by the antibodies. This approach can be used to understand the mechanisms of other autoimmune encephalitis. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. The cause of this warming is unknown, but it is likely due to a combination of anthropogenic and natural factors. Here, we present a case study of a natural warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma and was accompanied by a rapid increase in atmospheric CO2. We show that this warming was accompanied by an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean, anoxia of the ocean floor, and a biodiversity nadir. Our results provide insights into the Earth system’s response to abrupt warming and can be used to better understand the current warming. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and many governments and corporations have made commitments to reduce this impact. Certification is the primary tool used to fulfill these commitments, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been quantified. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, but that certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in forested regions and the need for certification to be tightly linked to the effective protection of forests. This is particularly important in Indonesia, where the majority of certified oil palm plantations are located.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is a promising target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. However, the study of the regulation of the exocyst complex is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes in the currently available mutants. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental trait in vertebrates, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In many species, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in a cichlid fish, where two alleles produce four possible sex classes. We find that the interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation produces modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and the acquisition of a new sex determination allele can produce additional axes of variation. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-induced photoproducts of vitamin A. We sought to understand how the levels of iron (Fe) impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoid lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. In albino mice with reduced levels of Fe, as a result of treatment with the Fe chelator deferiprone, the levels of bisretinoids were reduced. In mice with increased levels of Fe, as a result of deficiency in the Fe export proteins hephaestin and ceruloplasmin, the levels of bisretinoids were reduced. These findings indicate that Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key factor in the development of trophic webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is associated with the evolution of morphological and functional modularity. Our findings contribute to a broader understanding of the evolution of specialization in predators, and how it has shaped the present-day food web.

The human hand is a complex and highly evolved structure. The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution, as it is the foundation for the emergence of the distinctive tool-using abilities of the genus Homo. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the evolution of the human hand was a more rapid process than previously thought.

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus one-carbon metabolism is a critical metabolic pathway. In this study, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells, namely, the deficiency of one-carbon metabolism. We also identify a metabolic vulnerability of B-cell lymphoma, namely, the deficiency of glycine import. These findings have implications for cancer treatment and lymphoma therapy.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the loss of natural landscapes is a key contributor to the global nutrition crisis. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact is exacerbated by fragmentation of natural landscapes. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, and the need to protect and restore natural landscapes to improve people’s diets and the environment.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it comes at a cost of soil degradation. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a significant increase in subsoil compaction, which is now widespread over 20% of arable land. This trend has the potential to reduce soil productivity, and we hypothesize that this is a consequence of the increase in the weight of modern farm machinery. We suggest that the roaming of sauropods, the largest animals that walked Earth, may have been a strategy for reducing subsoil compaction, and we propose that this may have been a key factor in the success of these giants. Our results highlight the importance of the weight of farm machinery in the sustainability of modern agriculture. (Show more)
